subject: Productivity
title: Deming and Quality Management
description: A quick, practical guide to Deming and Quality Management.

hook.text: After World War Two, Japan's products were considered junk. One American statistician changed that.

buildup.text: W. Edwards Deming taught Japanese manufacturers that quality reduces waste and boosts productivity.

discovery.text: His Plan-Do-Check-Act cycle created a culture of continuous improvement. Defects plummeted.

twist.text: American companies ignored Deming for decades. Japan surpassed them in quality while America watched.

climax.text: By the 1980s, US firms finally adopted Deming's methods. He was 80 years old before his own country listened.

punchline.text: Quality and productivity aren't opposites. They're partners.

quiz.question: What did Deming teach Japanese manufacturers?
options: Quality reduces waste and boosts productivity
Speed is more important than quality
Workers should be replaced by machines
